query: What is the test for inventive step under Singapore patent law?
answer: Under Section 15 of the Patents Act, an invention is considered to involve an inventive step if it is not obvious to a person skilled in the art, having regard to any matter which forms part of the state of the art. This test was further clarified in First Currency Choice Pte Ltd v Main-Line Corporate Holdings Ltd [2008] where the Court of Appeal held that the invention must involve a technical advance that is not obvious. The court emphasized that the assessment should be made from the perspective of a person skilled in the relevant technical field, considering the common general knowledge available at the priority date.

context.content: Section 15 - Inventive step: An invention shall be taken to involve an inventive step if it is not obvious to a person skilled in the art, having regard to any matter which forms part of the state of the art by virtue only of section 14(2) (and disregarding section 14(3)).

First Currency Choice Pte Ltd v Main-Line Corporate Holdings Ltd [2008] SGCA 20: The Court of Appeal held that for an invention to involve an inventive step, it must not be obvious to a person skilled in the art. The assessment requires consideration of whether there is a technical advance that would not be obvious to the skilled person.

Muhlbauer AG v Manufacturing Integration Technology Ltd [2011] SGCA 30: The court reiterated that the inventive step test involves determining whether the invention would have been obvious to a person skilled in the art, taking into account the common general knowledge available at the priority date.
